docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal advisory panel suggested today that the nation consider investing part of its Social Security revenues in the stock market to insure the solvency of the retirement program. But panel members disagreed on whether workers or the Government should decide how the money is invested. Seven of the 13 panel members recommended compulsory private savings through individual investment accounts. Labor unions said they would fiercely resist the use of such accounts to replace any part of the Federal program.

headline.main: PANEL ON SOCIAL SECURITY URGES INVESTING IN STOCKS, BUT IS SPLIT OVER METHODS

docs.abstract: Advisory Council on Social Security, Federal advisory panel, suggests that nation consider investing part of Social Security revenues in stock market to insure solvency of retirement program; says program can obtain much higher return by investing money in stocks; members disagree on whether workers or Government should decide how money is invested; their recommendations discussed; graphs; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With an occasionally searching, even plaintive tone, President Clinton today appealed to the nation's clergy to help him create ''a sense of reconciliation, the right sort of spirit'' for the nation to grapple with its social problems. In remarks to an annual White House ecumenical breakfast that his aides said would begin to set the stage for his second inauguration, the President mentioned Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago, who died recently of cancer. Noting that the prelate said in a final speech that time should not be wasted on acrimony, Mr. Clinton added, ''He said that knowing that he had just a little bit of time left, when the truth is all of us have just a little bit of time left.''

headline.main: Clinton Seeks Help for the Nation's Spirit

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton meets with clergy at annual White House ecumenical breakfast; asks for help in creating sense of reconciliation and right sort of spirit needed to grapple with nation's social problems; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The intense pain in Chris Childs's lower back that prevented him from playing Sunday night has subsided, and he could play tonight against the Dallas Mavericks at Madison Square Garden. But the Knicks have another player with a health problem. Larry Johnson, who strained his left hamstring in the Knicks' 97-92 victory over Milwaukee on Sunday, is listed as doubtful for tonight.

headline.main: Childs May Play, but Johnson May Sit

docs.snippet: The intense pain in Chris Childs's lower back that prevented him from playing Sunday night has subsided, and he could play tonight against the Dallas Mavericks at Madison Square Garden. But the Knicks have another player with a health problem.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: As a new Congress convenes on Tuesday vowing to cut taxes, tame Medicare spending and balance the Federal budget, many in the Capitol believe the elements of success are in alignment for the first time in years, but only if the lawmakers can first deal with explosive ethical issues involving campaign finance and Speaker Newt Gingrich. The path of the new Congress is likely to be charted in its first weeks, when the House is expected to hold extraordinary public hearings and debate the fate of Mr. Gingrich. Perhaps a month later, in late February or early March, the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee will publicly investigate possible campaign-spending abuses by the Democratic Party, the White House and, probably, by Republicans as well.

headline.main: CONGRESS IS POISED FOR FRUITFUL YEAR AFTER SOME TESTS

docs.abstract: New Congress will convene with ambitious agenda, and, many lawmakers say, strong prospects for success despite significant hurdles; much augurs well for optimists since one out of every five House members is freshman, none of whom carries scars from political battles of last four years; timing is seen as important factor, since Pres Clinton, transformed from election-year rival to lame duck, needs help of Congress in winning place in history; populist fires that led Republicans into disastrous confrontations in 1995 and 1996 appear to have abated, and balance of legislative power has shifted to Senate, where Republican majority leader Sen Trent Lott likes to cut deals; some major issues facing new Congress discussed (M)
docs.snippet: As a new Congress convenes on Tuesday vowing to cut taxes, tame Medicare spending and balance the Federal budget, many in the Capitol believe the elements of success are in alignment for the first time in years, but only if the lawmakers can first...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Betsy Wade reported on the death of two travelers after yellow fever infection and notes that yellow fever prophylaxis is recommended by both the W.H.O. and the C.D.C. for travelers in parts of Africa and Latin America. While those who neglect vaccination may, to paraphrase Dr. Woodall's comments, be playing dice with their lives, Ms. Wade and your readers should be aware that immunizations for travel may not be covered by their health insurance.
docs.abstract: Letter by Dr Ross S Basch on Betsy Wade's Nov 24 Practical Traveler column on travel vaccines (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Celita Schutz is still in recovery, not so much from losing her first and only Olympic match, but from the intense high of getting to the Games and of being there. The experience has changed her, she thinks, although she is not sure how; she is still in the process of becoming. ''I've accepted I won't get rich playing judo, that I'll be buying my own shoes,'' she said last week. ''I do what I do because I enjoy it and I'm good at it and I want to keep moving and see where it takes me.''

headline.main: Atlanta Is in the Past. The World Is Waiting

docs.abstract: Article profiles career of American judo team member Celita Schutz; photo (M)t

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The column on travel vaccines appropriately stressed the importance of obtaining current information on vaccinations. But the same applies to all health-related travel advice, especially that gleaned from guidebooks, which, as Betsy Wade pointed out, is likely to be stale.
